newsitem.title: NORWAY: Norway says no talks held on aluminium MOU renewal.
newsitem.headline: Norway says no talks held on aluminium MOU renewal.

text.p: Norway said on Monday it was not in talks with other governments on the possible renewal of a gentleman's agreement to restrain growth in aluminium production.

Lars Olaf Selnes, advisor in the industrial policy department in the Ministry of Industry and Energy, said there had been no contacts on a governmental level since the Memorandum of Understanding between six major producing countries ran out earlier this year.
"I am not aware of any renewal of the agreement. There have not been talks on a government level since the expiry of the MOU," Selnes said.
Signatories to the two-year MOU, which was signed in March 1994, were the European Union, Norway, Australia, the United States, Canada and Russia.
The head of the Russian Kontsern Alyuminiy producers' association said on Monday that Russian producers had agreed not to raise aluminium output from current levels.
Igor Prokopov said other countries had agreed to do the same.
"I've never heard of this before," Norway's Selnes said.
